subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage suspected bacterial meningitis without a non-blanching rash?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange emergency medical transfer to hospital by telephoning 999. 
  • Do not give parenteral antibiotic treatment unless urgent transfer to hospital is not possible (for example in remote locations or owing to adverse weather conditions). 
    • Choice of empiric antibiotic will depend on availability or local policy. 
      • Options include benzylpenicillin, cefotaxime, or chloramphenicol. 
  • If the person has no specific clinical features of bacterial meningitis, but it is not possible to exclude the person being in the early stages of the disease, admit to secondary care for a full assessment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Bacterial meningitis and meningococcal septicaemia in children [NICE, 2018] and Sepsis: recognition, diagnosis and early management [NICE, 2017a], the Meningitis Research Foundation (MRF) booklet Meningococcal meningitis and sepsis. Guidance notes: diagnosis and treatment in general practice [Meningitis Research Foundation, 2018], and the British National Formulary (BNF) [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020].

Not routinely giving pre-hospital parenteral antibiotics in people with suspected meningitis without non-blanching rash
  • For children and young people with suspected meningitis without non-blanching rash, the NICE guideline development group (GDG) did not recommend giving pre-hospital parenteral antibiotics (unless urgent transfer to hospital is not possible) because [NICE, 2018]:
    • It found no high-quality evidence on the effects of pre-hospital antibiotics in children and young people with suspected bacterial meningitis.
    • It highlights that it is more usual to administer antibiotics in hospital than in primary care for these people. This is because:
      • The rate of progression of the disease is slower when compared with septicaemia.
      • Lumbar puncture is usually performed before antibiotic administration. If lumbar puncture is not performed, it is difficult to distinguish bacterial meningitis from other illnesses that do not require antibiotic treatment.
      • Corticosteroids are used as adjunctive therapy for bacterial meningitis, and these should be administered before or with the first dose of antibiotics.
      • Antibiotic treatment should therefore be delayed until the diagnosis has been made by lumbar puncture in secondary care.
Antibiotic choice if urgent transfer to hospital is not possible
    • These recommends are based on the BNF and the MRF guideline [Meningitis Research Foundation, 2018].
    • The BNF advises that [Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]:
      • If a patient with suspected bacterial meningitis without non-blanching rash cannot be transferred to hospital urgently, a single dose of benzylpenicillin should be given before the transfer. 
      • In people with penicillin allergy, cefotaxime may be an alternative and chloramphenicol may be used if there is a history of immediate hypersensitivity reaction to penicillin or to cephalosporins.
Admitting to hospital if it is not possible to exclude early bacterial meningitis
  • This recommendation is pragmatic and is based on the serious medical consequences of misdiagnosing meningococcal disease, as highlighted by NICE [NICE, 2018] and the Medical Defence Union [MDU, 2013].
